Award.AwardTitle: Activatable Fluorescent Protein/Metal Hybrid Raman Nano-Probes for Biosensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical:

This award by the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research to the University of Southern California is to develop probes that are activatable fluorescent protein/metal hybrids that will be useful in Surface Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) for biosensing. Detecting individual pathogenic cells and eliminating them is crucial for early cancer detection and treatments. Raman nanoprobes are among a handful of probes that could provide such high detection sensitivity. Yet, current formulations are molecularly bulky and lacking in specificity and sensitivity, which ultimately limits their efficacy in research and medical settings. This project offers a novel design and implementation of Raman nanoprobes for biosensing, with the goal of achieving highly sensitive but specific detection of cancer cells. Educational and outreach components are an integral part of the project. The proposed activities engage participating researchers and students in highly interdisciplinary research to prepare the next generation of scientists to face the growing demands for interdisciplinary skills at the interface between physics, chemistry and biology. The program also integrates modern technology and interdisciplinary science for young students. Mentoring and cross-disciplinary training of traditionally underrepresented undergraduate and high-school students on emerging nanotechnology methods and on the use of advanced photonic instrumentations will be realized through established programs at the University of Southern California, through partnership with non-profit organizations and through outreach to high-schools in the Greater Los Angeles area.


Technical:

Plasmonic Raman nanoprobes are highly promising agents for the next generation of biomedical imaging and treatment but current limitations in their design, including large sizes (>100 nm) and poor Raman signals, significantly impede their potential for major breakthroughs in molecular imaging and theranostics. This project will investigate the use of split-fluorescent proteins as both molecular glue and Raman reporters for cell-directed assembly of small and activatable surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) metal nanoprobes, with the aim of achieving highly sensitive and specific Raman detection of cancer cells. The project offers a novel approach to SERS biosensing and detection and may allow significant advances in the basic understanding of (i) photonic properties emerging at natural chromophore/metal nanoparticle interfaces, (ii) Raman enhancement processes in well-defined nanostructures and (iii) molecular factors affecting the assembly of nanomaterials into controlled nanoclusters in live cells. The studies are expected to contribute knowledge and techniques that will be broadly useful for the directed assembly of nanoparticles into metamaterials and into catalytic/electronic nanostructures to be used in biomedical, prosthetics, therapeutics and fundamental research applications. An integral part of this project is the training and mentoring of underrepresented students in interdisciplinary research in nanotechnology, biomaterials and photonics, through the integration of research findings and instrumentation into classroom teaching, outreach programs to local high-schools, and general public presentations. Significant enhancement of the infrastructure for research and education at the University of Southern California is also provided by the implementation of an optical set-up for single molecule SERS measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The recent convergence of biotechnology and nanotechnology has opened new avenues to design hybrid nanomaterials for biomedical applications. For instance, small adhesive biomolecules can be used as construction material to carefully assemble metal nanoparticles into nanoscale clusters and biosensors for the bioanalyses of diseases.

 Historically, nucleic acids and DNA origami have been the building blocks of choice for the controlled bottom-up assembly of nanoparticles (NPs) into photonic nanoclusters. In vitro, complementary DNA fragments functionalized with Raman reporters are often employed to assemble gold (Au) or silver (Ag) NPs into Raman probes. When these nanoprobes are excited with light, interparticle plasmon-plasmon couplings within nanometer size gaps between clustered NPs produce plasmonic hot-spots where massive near-field electromagnetic amplifications enable very high sensitivity detections of the Raman reporters by surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). Assembling such hot-spot SERS nanoclusters directly in living cells is the next frontier in the field, which could open tremendous opportunities for biomedical research, including in vivo targeting and SERS detection of individual pathogenic cells. Up to now, this has proven to be very challenging using nucleic acids as assembly material for metal NPs because DNA scaffolds are rapidly degraded by nucleases and are very susceptible to pH and ion concentrations in biological buffers. This has limited their use for the remote assembly of SERS clusters in cells and in vivo.

This project tackled these issues by pioneering a novel strategy to assemble metal NPs into hot-spot SERS nanoclusters in living cells, using complementary split-green fluorescent protein (split-GFP) fragments as organizing scaffolds rather than DNA. Split-GFP fragments are complementary domains from a super-folder GFP that is split into two asymmetric pieces: a large GFP 1–10 domain (amino acids 1–214) and a smaller peptide domain that corresponds to the 11th β-sheet of the super-folder GFP β-barrel structure (amino acids 215–230). Both fragments spontaneously and irreversibly self-assemble in solution to form a fully folded GFP with a mature peptide-chromophore. The chromophore, once structured, displays peculiar Raman vibrational fingerprints that can be detected among the vibrational modes of all other biomolecules (e.g. DNA, lipids, proteins, etc…).

The project demonstrated that when these complementary fragments are grafted on different Au or Ag metal colloids, they guide the self-assembly of NPs into clusters, induce the folding of a full-length GFP within 2 nm size plasmonic hot-spots between NPs and trigger the autocatalytic maturation of the GFP chromophore, thus allowing massive SERS enhancement of its vibrational fingerprints. The project also established that this assembly process is applicable to different sizes (10-40 nm), shape (nanospheres and nanorods) and composition (Au and Ag) of nanomaterials. This assembly can also be performed with a variety of split-FP fragments, including novel split-GFP, split-yellow fluorescent proteins (split-YFP) and split-cyan fluorescent proteins (split-CFP), which have been engineered and for which detailed biochemical and photophysical characterizations have been provided (e.g. kinetics of fragment self-assembly, kinetics of chromophore maturation, photostability, lifetime, etc…). During the project, extensive theoretical frameworks were also provided to define and optimize the mechanisms for nanoplasmonic enhancements that lead to the massive SERS of the chromophore at different spectral wavelengths and for a variety of GFP/metal NP cluster sizes and shapes. This theoretical work was further validated by experimental SERS measurements. The project also confirmed that biofunctionalized metal NPs targeted to various cell surface biomarkers effectively assemble into hot-spot SERS nanoclusters in cells and provide specific and high sensitivity detection of cancer cells over normal primary cells by SERS microscopy imaging. The molecular mechanisms underlying the controlled assembly of NP clusters in cells have also been defined. Finally, the project showed that these GFP/NP hybrid nanoclusters additionally provide as second imaging modality of targeted cancer cells by photoacoustic detection, therefore allowing multimodal SERS and photoacoustic microscopy of individual cancer cells in complex biological environments.

 Altogether, the project has:

1-     Provided a novel alternative to the traditional DNA-based assemblies of functional nanomaterials.

2-     Tackled a conundrum in the field of nanoplasmonics, which involved forming bottom-up nanostructures with well-defined and homogenous plasmonic hot-spots for high sensitivity Raman biosensing.

3-     Contributed in-depth understandings of the photonic properties emerging within plasmonic hot-spots for hybrid SERS nanoclusters having various shapes and compositions.

4-     Addressed the challenge of assembling and activating plasmonic nanoantennas in a site-specific manner directly in live cells.

5-     Provided novel optical probes for highly specific cancer cell detections with dual imaging modality (SERS and photoacoustic).

6-     Provided a panel of new split-fluorescent proteins for SERS detection or traditional fluorescence imaging.
